Claude Code EAP Report

Opus 4.5 vs Opus 4.6: Behavioral Patterns in Practice

An exploratory single-user case study across 1,944 tasks—observational findings, not controlled comparison
Samuel H. Christie V · February 2026 · Claude Code Early Access Program

1. Executive Summary

Rewrite Rate
17.1% vs 8.8%
4.5: n=642, 4.6: n=29 editing tasks
Per-Task Cost
−12 to −47%
4.6 cheaper trivial through moderate
Output Token Ratio
1.4×
4.6: 1,322 avg vs 4.5: 963 avg
Bonferroni Survivors
8 / 115
Lines metrics, tools/file, 5 distributions
Study design note: This is a single-user observational study with non-random task assignment. Opus 4.5 data spans 2 months across 31 projects (1,742 tasks); Opus 4.6 spans 5 days across 4 projects (202 tasks). Differences may reflect the user, project mix, or time period rather than model capabilities. All findings should be treated as hypotheses for future testing.

Observed patterns suggest the two models work differently at comparable success rates. Opus 4.6 uses 68% more tool calls, deploys subagents that are 94% read-only research, and plans more often. Of 115 statistical tests with Bonferroni correction, eight survive—mostly about how each model works (tool usage, distributions), not whether they succeed. Several initial findings were reversed during analysis when more direct signals became available (§11).

The observed data is consistent with a pattern where Opus 4.5 acts first and adjusts as needed while Opus 4.6 investigates first and implements in concentrated bursts—but the confounded study design means this characterization is tentative. This report examines where observed patterns diverge, ordered from the strongest signals (cost, tool usage) through behavioral mechanics to weaker observational patterns.

Contents & Key Findings
Dataset at a Glance368 sessions, 1,944 tasks, 31 projects, $6,109 total cost
  1. Token Economy & Cost4.6 appears 12–47% cheaper at trivial through moderate despite 1.4× more output tokens
  2. Edit Accuracy4.5: 17.1% rewrite rate (n=642); 4.6: 8.8% (n=29)—wide CIs overlap
  3. Quality & SatisfactionBoth under 0.4% dissatisfaction; completion and failure rates differ
  4. Behavioral Patterns4.5 deploys more subagents; 4.6’s are 94% read-only Explore agents
  5. Complexity & Resource UsageTool usage gap is the strongest statistical signal (p<0.000003)
  6. Planning: Correlation vs Causation8.7% planning rate (4.6), 1.9% (4.5); small alignment benefit but n<20
  7. Context Window & Compaction1 compaction event across 252 analyzed sessions (Opus 4.5 only)
  8. Session DynamicsObserved patterns suggest 4.6 may benefit more from session context
  9. Model ProfilesObserved behavioral patterns (not routing recommendations)
  10. MethodologyPipeline, development process, and limitations

Dataset at a Glance

Sessions Analyzed

327 (4.5) + 41 (4.6)
Tasks Extracted
1,944
1,742 (4.5) + 202 (4.6)
Projects Spanned

4 shared between both models
Total API Cost
$6,109
$5,327 (4.5) + $781 (4.6)

All data comes from a single user's organic Claude Code sessions between December 2025 and February 2026. The dataset is intentionally asymmetric: Opus 4.5 served as the primary model for two months, while Opus 4.6 entered evaluation in early February. This means Opus 4.5 totals are larger in absolute terms, but per-task and per-session comparisons normalize for this. Where sample size limits statistical power, the report notes it explicitly.

Per-model composition

The dataset reflects organic usage patterns, not a controlled experiment. Opus 4.5 accumulated sessions over two months of daily use; Opus 4.6 entered evaluation in early February 2026.

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6 Combined
Sessions 327 41 368
Tasks 1,742 202 1,944
Tasks / session 5.3 4.9 5.3
Projects 31 4 31
Date range Dec 5 – Feb 10 Feb 5 – Feb 10 Dec 5 – Feb 10
User messages 20,537 3,871 24,408
Tool calls 17,987 3,504 21,491

The 8:1 session ratio means per-task averages for Opus 4.5 are more robust, while Opus 4.6 estimates carry wider confidence intervals. Opus 4.6 sessions are concentrated across 4 projects (all of which also have Opus 4.5 sessions), providing natural overlap for matched-pair comparisons where they apply.

Complexity is inferred from tool count, files touched, and lines changed. Over half of all tasks are trivial (single-turn interactions), while major tasks (>50 tool calls or >500 lines) represent ~1% of volume but a significant share of cost.

The task type distributions are broadly similar across models, suggesting the user's work patterns remained consistent. The complexity mix is also comparable, though Opus 4.6 has a slightly higher share of moderate-and-above tasks (40.1% vs 33.2%), likely reflecting the evaluation period's focus on substantive work rather than quick queries.

Raw token volumes across the full dataset. These are absolute totals, not per-task averages (see §2 for normalized comparisons).

Output composition

Model output splits into thinking (extended thinking / chain-of-thought, not billed as output) and text (visible response, code, tool calls). Estimated from character counts with a 3:1 chars-to-tokens ratio for thinking.

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
Est. thinking tokens 1,431,583 216,699
Est. text tokens 675,583 160,923
Thinking ratio (tasks using thinking) 75.5% 59.4%
Avg requests / task 7.4 10.3

Code output

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6 Combined
Files touched 2,915 425 3,340
Lines added 179,590 13,576 193,166
Lines removed 37,786 3,097 40,883

Cache reads dominate the token budget: 90% of all tokens processed were served from cache rather than freshly encoded. This reflects Claude Code's prompt architecture, where the system prompt and conversation history are re-sent with each API call but largely hit the prompt cache.

2. Token Economy & Cost

Extracting API usage data from session logs reveals how each model allocates its computational budget. Despite producing more output tokens and making more API round-trips (10.3 vs 7.4 requests/task), Opus 4.6 shows lower per-task costs at trivial through moderate levels, likely reflecting higher cache hit rates from concentrated project usage during the shorter 4.6 evaluation period.

Per-Task Cost
~$2.64
$2.46 (4.5) vs $2.83 (4.6)
Output Token Ratio
1.4×
4.6 produces 1,322 vs 963 avg tokens
Thinking Depth Gap
+51%
3,965 vs 2,625 chars when thinking
Total Cost Analyzed
$6,109
$5,327 (4.5) + $781 (4.6)

Thinking Calibration

Opus 4.5 thinks more often (76% of tasks) but shallowly. Opus 4.6 thinks less often (59%) but more deeply when it does. The pattern reverses at the complexity extremes:

Thinking calibration: Opus 4.6 shows better calibration of when thinking is needed. It skips thinking for 63% of trivial tasks (vs 23% for Opus 4.5), but engages thinking for 98% of moderate tasks (vs 90%). Opus 4.5 over-thinks easy problems; at moderate complexity, 4.6 shows higher thinking engagement.

The 2.9× ratio for refactoring is notable: Opus 4.6 produces substantially more output tokens for refactoring tasks, suggesting more thorough changes. For continuation tasks (follow-ups within a session), Opus 4.6 produces 0.6× the output volume of Opus 4.5—suggesting it maintains conciseness throughout.

Cost by Complexity

ComplexityCost Comparison4.5 avg cost4.6 avg costΔ

$0.86

 $0.86$0.52−40%

$3.07
 $3.51$3.07−12%

B
$7.48
 $7.27$7.48+3%
Major
A
$12.79
B
$20.90
 $12.79$20.90+63%

Normalizing by session hours rather than task count reinforces the per-task finding: Opus 4.5 costs $12.75/session-hour ($5,327 over 417.9h) vs $7.51/session-hour for Opus 4.6 ($781 over 104.0h)—a 41% reduction. Session hours measure wall-clock time from first to last message, so this metric includes idle time and is not a direct measure of active coding cost. Still, it confirms the per-task cost advantage extends to session-level efficiency.

Counter-intuitive cost finding (with caveats): Despite producing more output tokens, Opus 4.6 appears 12–47% cheaper per task from trivial through moderate levels, likely from more efficient prompt caching. The exception is major tasks, where 4.6 costs +63% more—but this is based on 5 4.6 major tasks vs 18 for 4.5, so the estimate is unreliable. These figures come from organic sessions where task mix, session structure, and user behavior differ between models. Without more controlled experiments, per-complexity cost advantages should be interpreted cautiously—some of the gap may reflect differences in how the models were used rather than inherent efficiency.
Token breakdown by complexity level

Per-task average token usage driving the cost differences. Opus 4.6 produces more output but uses less fresh input, relying more on cached context:

Complexity 4.5 output/task 4.6 output/task 4.5 input/task 4.6 input/task 4.5 requests 4.6 requests
Trivial 97 94 14 17 1.6 1.9
Simple 533 417 135 37 5.7 5.2
Moderate 1,512 1,550 598 133 11.4 11.7
Complex 3,990 4,350 1,479 33 26.5 28.2
Major 8,872 10,919 2,133 79 52.0 76.2

At complex tasks, Opus 4.6 uses dramatically fewer fresh input tokens per task (33 vs 1,479) while producing 9% more output (4,350 vs 3,990). Despite using similar request counts per task at the complex level (28.2 vs 26.5), Opus 4.6 achieves much more effective cache utilization. Combined with more effective cache utilization, the output cost premium is more than offset by input savings.

Caveat: These averages come from organic sessions with different task mixes per model. Some of the per-complexity gap may reflect session-level factors (e.g., caching benefits accumulate within longer sessions).

3. Edit Accuracy

Cost efficiency tells us about resource usage, but a more fundamental question is accuracy. How often does each model produce output that needs rework? Edit timeline analysis tracks every Edit and Write tool call per session, detecting when a later edit’s old_string overlaps with an earlier edit’s new_string on the same file.

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
MetricDistribution4.54.6
Tasks with edits64229
Edit calls (rewrite rate denom.)2,302102

Full edit overlap breakdown
MetricOpus 4.5Opus 4.6
Total edits + writes2,302 + 762102 + 42
Overlapping edits393 (17.1%)9 (8.8%)
— Exact match258 (65.6%)9 (100.0%)
— Containment48 (12.2%)0 (0.0%)
— Line overlap87 (22.1%)0 (0.0%)

Classification of what drove the rework:

CauseOpus 4.5Opus 4.6
Self-correction37 (9.4%)5 (55.6%)
Error recovery59 (15.0%)0 (0.0%)
User-directed42 (10.7%)0 (0.0%)
Iterative refinement255 (64.9%)4 (44.4%)

Classification

Each detected overlap is classified by context:

  • Self-correction: Agent rewrites its own output within the same task, no intervening error—catching and fixing its own mistakes unprompted.
  • Error recovery: Same task, but a tool error (test failure, syntax error, compilation failure) occurred between the original edit and the rewrite.
  • User-directed correction: The rewrite occurs in a later task, and the intervening user message contains dissatisfaction signals (“wrong”, “revert”, “fix that”, etc.).
  • Iterative refinement: Sequential edits to the same region without error signals or dissatisfaction—normal iterative development.

Opus 4.6 self-corrects at a higher rate than Opus 4.5 (55.6% vs 9.4% of overlapping edits), but has zero error recoveries (vs 15.0% for Opus 4.5). Opus 4.5 triggered 42 user-directed corrections (10.7% of overlaps); Opus 4.6 triggered none. The overall rewrite rate (17.1% vs 8.8%) is the strongest accuracy signal: Opus 4.5 rewrites previously-edited regions 1.9× as often as Opus 4.6.

Iterative Refinement: Workflow or Strategy?

The aggregate iterative refinement gap invites the question: does Opus 4.5 genuinely iterate more, or does the gap reflect different usage patterns? Breaking it down by complexity reveals a striking pattern:

ComplexityIterative Refinement Rate4.5 (n)4.6 (n)
Trivial

B
0.0%

Moderate

B
8.7%

Complex+
A
0.0%
B
0.0%
 010

At the complex+ end, both models show low iteration counts (0 for 4.5 vs 6 edits for 4.6), and the moderate gap is modest (12.4% vs 8.7%). The gap is concentrated in trivial and simple tasks—exactly the categories where workflow differences (user participation, task granularity, self-selection) are strongest.

The iterative refinement gap is substantially a workflow artifact rather than a pure model-strategy difference. The more robust accuracy signal is the overall rewrite rate, which controls for these confounds.

Accuracy by Complexity

Does the rewrite pattern hold across task complexity levels, or is it concentrated in specific bins? Joining edit metrics with task classifications (82% coverage for Opus 4.5, 83% for Opus 4.6) reveals the pattern:

ComplexitySelf-Correction Rate4.5 (n)4.6 (n)
Trivial
A
0.0%
B
0.0%

Simple

B

Moderate

1.8%
B
2.2%

Complex+
A
0.0%
B
4.4%
 010

User-directed corrections total 42 for Opus 4.5 and zero for Opus 4.6. The small sample sizes per bin (especially 4.6’s 4 complex+ edits) limit confidence in bin-level comparisons.

The same pattern appears when binning by task duration: Opus 4.5 self-corrects at 8.3–26.8% across short/medium/long terciles, while rates vary across bins for both models.

Bottom line: When errors occur, the models handle them differently. Opus 4.6 catches its own mistakes (55.6% self-correction rate) while Opus 4.5 more often needs external feedback (42 user-directed corrections vs zero, 15.0% error recovery vs 0%). The iterative refinement gap largely disappears for complex tasks, suggesting it reflects workflow differences. The overall rewrite rate (17.1% vs 8.8%) remains the most robust accuracy signal.

Opus 4.6 completes a higher fraction of tasks outright (+2.0pp) and fails less often (−5.8pp). The failure rate difference is statistically significant (p=0.024) though the effect size is negligible (Cohen's h=0.18). Both models interrupt at similar rates, suggesting the difference comes from converting partial completions into full completions rather than avoiding interruptions.

Significance: Alignment gap (p=0.005735, d=-0.21) is significant at p<0.05 but marginal after Bonferroni correction (threshold: p<0.00043). Failure rate (p=0.024) and completion rate (p=0.552) significant at p<0.05 but not after correction. Satisfaction/dissatisfaction differences not significant.

Bonferroni Correction

With 9 independent tests conducted (1 Mann-Whitney U, 7 proportion tests, 1 chi-square), the Bonferroni-corrected significance threshold is Î± = 0.05 / 9 = 0.0056.

Tests surviving Bonferroni correction (p < 0.0056):

  • Task completion distribution: p = 0.000079 (significant)

Tests significant at Î± = 0.05 but not after correction:

  • Alignment score: p = 0.0057 (marginal)
  • Failed Rate: p = 0.0236 (marginal)

Non-significant tests:

  • Satisfaction Rate: p = 0.837 (both models 0%)
  • Dissatisfaction Rate: p = 0.648 (both models 0%)
  • Complete Rate: p = 0.552
  • Scope Expanded Rate: p = 0.131
  • One Shot Rate: p = 0.827
  • Good Execution Rate: p = 0.709

LLM-annotated dissatisfaction is extremely low for both models (<0.4%). Satisfaction and dissatisfaction differences between models are not statistically significant. Edit timeline analysis (§3) provides a more direct accuracy signal that confirms the same direction: Opus 4.6 produces fewer edits requiring rework.

The invisible subagent: Opus 4.5 deploys far more total subagents (212 vs 18) but they serve different purposes. For Opus 4.6, 94% are lightweight, read-only Explore agents that quietly gather context before implementation begins. Opus 4.5 splits its subagents more evenly—37% are general-purpose implementation workers that visibly modify files. The models produce comparable output, but Opus 4.6 front-loads research while Opus 4.5 front-loads action.
Significance: Autonomy level (p=0.007, V=0.10) and one-shot rate (p=0.004, h=−0.16) significant at p<0.05 but not after Bonferroni correction.

 103.1 67.2 A +35%
Significance: Tool calls/task (p=0.000002, d=−0.29) and tools/file (p=0.000003, d=−0.18) survive Bonferroni correction—among the strongest signals in the study. Lines-added difference is also Bonferroni-significant.
The exploration–satisfaction tradeoff: Opus 4.6 uses 68% more tool calls per task yet produces 35% fewer lines of code. The extra activity is research, not output. This research correlates with higher alignment (+0.27) and completion (+2.0pp), but the marginal value of each additional tool call diminishes—68% more tool overhead yields a small-effect improvement.

7. Planning: Correlation vs Causation

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
MetricDistribution4.54.6
Planning adoption rate
A
1.9%
B
8.7%
 29 tasks 9 tasks

Opus 4.5 rarely enters plan mode (1.9%, 29 of 1,531 tasks), while Opus 4.6 plans on 8.7% of tasks (9 of 104). The alignment benefit is substantial but based on very small samples: planned tasks score higher than unplanned tasks (4.5: 3.48 vs 2.95; 4.6: 3.22 vs 3.19).

Planning Rate by Task Complexity

 8/304 2/27

63.6%
 20/155 7/11

Opus 4.5 rarely plans (1.9% overall). Opus 4.6 concentrates its planning on harder tasks: 63.6% of complex+ tasks and 7.4% of moderate tasks, with no planning for trivial or simple tasks. Neither model plans for trivial tasks.

Planning alignment by complexity bin
Opus 4.5Opus 4.6
ComplexityPlannedUnplannedΔPlannedUnplannedΔ
Trivial — (n=0)2.55 (n=767)— — (n=0)3.12 (n=41)—
Simple 3.00 (n=1)3.34 (n=304)−0.34 — (n=0)2.84 (n=25)—
Moderate 3.88 (n=8)3.30 (n=296)+0.57 3.50 (n=2)3.64 (n=25)−0.14
Complex+ 3.35 (n=20)3.51 (n=135)−0.16 3.14 (n=7)3.25 (n=4)−0.11
Insufficient evidence that planning is necessary: Although Opus 4.6 is the only model that plans, this data alone cannot establish that planning causes its better outcomes. For complex+ tasks, planned tasks score lower (3.14 vs 3.25), based on 7 planned tasks vs 4 unplanned tasks. Furthermore, 9 of Opus 4.6’s 104 classified tasks use planning, making any causal claim extremely fragile. The same disposition that leads 4.6 to plan also leads it to explore more, use more subagents, and investigate before acting; planning may be a symptom of thoroughness rather than its mechanism. A controlled experiment (forcing planning on/off) would be needed to isolate the effect.

8. Context Window & Compaction

Claude Code compacts the conversation when the context window fills, summarizing earlier messages to free space. Community discussion has speculated that Opus 4.6’s higher token usage might lead to more frequent compaction. Compaction was extremely rare: Opus 4.5 triggered 1 compaction event in 1 of 231 sessions (0.4%), while Opus 4.6 had none across 21 sessions. With only a single event, compaction is essentially a non-factor in this dataset, though the one compacting session does provide a limited before/after comparison.

Opus 4.5 shows no warm-up effect: alignment stays flat at 2.85 between early and later tasks. Opus 4.6 improves from 2.95 to 3.06 in alignment and from 25.0% to 33.5% in completion rate, suggesting it benefits more from accumulated session context.

Research-first vs balanced: Opus 4.6 allocates 35% of tool calls to research (Read, Grep, Glob, Explore agents) vs 28% for Opus 4.5, with a correspondingly lower implementation ratio (17.5% vs 27.0%). Opus 4.6 also front-loads research more aggressively—59.3% of tasks show positive front-loading vs 54.3%. It investigates first, then implements in concentrated bursts.

Significance: Duration (p=0.015, d=−0.02) and iteration rate (p=0.018, V=0.10) significant at p<0.05 but not after Bonferroni correction. These effects are observational and confounded with task selection.

Both models degrade in longer sessions, but Opus 4.6 degrades more steeply: from 3.53 to 2.96 in alignment (−0.57) vs 2.93 to 2.85 (−0.08) for Opus 4.5. However, Opus 4.6 scores higher than Opus 4.5 in every session-length bucket—even in long sessions (2.96 vs 2.85). The steeper decline reflects 4.6’s higher baseline, not a crossover where 4.5 becomes preferable.

Opus 4.6 tasks skew longer: median 58.7s vs 41.5s, with a smaller share under 30s (34.9% vs 42.7%) and a larger share in the 2–10 minute range (24.2% vs 21.0%). The mean tells a different story—4.5’s 395.6s vs 4.6’s 177.8s—driven by a long tail of outlier sessions in the 4.5 data. The median is a more reliable measure here.

Notably, Opus 4.6 has a higher continuation task rate (4.7% vs 2.4% of classified tasks), counter to the hypothesis that its higher per-task cost reflects fewer user interventions. Instead, 4.6 simply takes longer per individual task, spending more tool calls on research before implementation (see §9 Effort Distribution above).

10. Model Profiles

Opus 4.5 — Observed Pattern

Observed approach: Tends to act first and adjust as needed. Jumps to implementation with minimal upfront research.

Subagents: 37% general-purpose (implementation workers), 49% Explore. Primarily autonomous (55%).

Planning: Rarely uses planning mode (1.9%). Distributes research evenly through the task.

Observed strengths: Efficient on trivial and simple tasks. Lower tool overhead. Stable performance across session lengths.

Observed weaknesses: Higher failure rate on complex tasks. Higher rewrite rate (17.1%) may indicate missed requirements.

Opus 4.6 — Observed Pattern

Observed approach: Tends to research first, then implement in focused bursts. Front-loads investigation before touching files.

Subagents: 94% Explore (read-only research), 0% general-purpose. Evenly split autonomous/user-directed (50%).

Planning: Occasionally self-initiates planning (8.7% of tasks, 9 of 104).

Observed strengths: Higher completion rate (+2.0pp), lower failure rate (−5.8pp). Lower rewrite rate (8.8%, n=29 tasks).

Observed weaknesses: Higher tool overhead (68% more calls). Performance may degrade in long sessions.

Observed Patterns by Task Type

Caveat: These patterns are observational, from a single user with non-random task assignment. They should be treated as hypotheses for controlled testing, not as routing recommendations.

Task TypeObserved PatternEvidence & Caveats
Trivial / simple tasksSimilar outcomes4.5 slightly cheaper; 4.6 shows lower rewrite rate but sample is small (n=29 editing tasks)
Complex / major tasks4.6 showed higher alignmentSmall sample (n=15 complex+major for 4.6); confounded by project differences
Refactoring4.6 showed fewer rewrites8.8% vs 17.1% rewrite rate; CIs overlap substantially at 4.6’s sample size
Investigation / research4.6 used more Explore agents94% read-only subagents; consistent with research-first pattern
Long sessions (9+ tasks)Both show some degradation4.6 may degrade faster but still scored higher; small sample for late-session tasks
Parallel execution4.6 backgrounded more tasks4.5 spawned more agents but ran them sequentially

11. Methodology

→
Token Extractioncost, verbosity
→
Statistical Tests115 comparisons

Edit Timeline2,948 edits
→
Compaction1 event
→
Report Buildterms, expansions
Data Cleaning Methodology

Task-level data cleaning applied four exclusion rules and four informational flags to canonical tasks before analysis. Exclusions remove tasks that do not represent genuine user-model interactions; flags annotate tasks with contextual metadata without removing them.

Exclusion Rules

RuleDescriptionOpus 4.5Opus 4.6
slash_commandTask prompt is a slash command (/command) or <command-name> tag — these invoke built-in features, not model reasoning——
system_continuationAutomatic continuations triggered by the system (e.g., context compaction boundaries, session resumptions) rather than deliberate user prompts——
empty_continuationBare acknowledgement prompts ("continue", "ok", "yes") with zero tool calls and <5s duration — the model produced no meaningful work——
no_response_interruptTasks where the model produced zero output (0 tool calls, 0 duration) before the session ended, typically user cancellations——

Informational Flags

These flags are preserved on included tasks for subgroup analysis but do not trigger exclusion:

  • meta — Task occurred within a meta-analysis session (e.g., this report's own development), where the model analyzed its own output
  • no_project — No project directory was associated with the session
  • interrupted — User interrupted the model mid-response (based on session end pattern)
  • post_compaction — Task occurred after a context compaction event in the same session, potentially with degraded context

Project Overlap & Sensitivity Analysis

A potential confound arises from unequal project coverage between models. To quantify this, a sensitivity analysis compares all statistical tests on the full dataset against a restricted subset containing only tasks from projects where both models were active. If results agree across both analyses, the project confound is unlikely to explain observed differences.

Each Claude Code session was segmented into tasks based on user-message boundaries and topic shifts. An LLM annotator classified each task for complexity, type, sentiment, completion status, and alignment score (1–5 scale). Behavioral metrics—subagent usage, planning, parallelization—were extracted from tool-call logs.

Edit timeline analysis tracked 3,208 Edit/Write tool calls across all sessions, building per-file content ownership maps to detect when a later edit’s old_string overlaps with an earlier edit’s new_string. Overlaps are detected via three tiers (exact match, containment at ≥30% ratio, and Jaccard line overlap) and classified by context (self-correction, error recovery, user-directed, iterative refinement). Edit metrics were joined with task classifications to compute complexity-binned accuracy rates (93% and 88% coverage for the two models).

Compaction analysis found 1 compact_boundary system message across 1 compacting session, extracting trigger type, pre-compaction token count, and position. Outcome impact was measured by splitting tasks into pre/post groups at the first compaction timestamp, with a control group of non-compacting sessions split at the median compaction position to isolate position effects.

Statistical testing: 115 tests were conducted: chi-square (categorical), Mann-Whitney U (continuous), proportion tests (rates). Bonferroni-corrected threshold: p<0.00043. Eight findings survive correction: tool calls, tools per file, and six categorical distributions (task completion, scope management, iteration required, error recovery, communication quality, autonomy level). Significance notes appear inline in each section.

Development Process

This analysis was developed iteratively. Several approaches were tried and abandoned when they proved unreliable:

Automated dissatisfaction detection (abandoned as primary signal): Initial LLM-based sentiment classification flagged 7–9% dissatisfaction for both models. LLM-agent audit of all 59 flagged cases revealed 73–93% false positive rates—the classifiers were fooled by task-coordination language (e.g., “fix” in subagent prompts). This approach was replaced by edit timeline analysis, which detects self-corrections mechanistically rather than through sentiment proxies.

LLM quality judgement (dropped): An LLM judge was asked to compare code quality between models. The results were unreliable—the judge lacked sufficient context to evaluate whether code met domain requirements, and produced confident but ungrounded assessments. This section was removed entirely rather than presented with caveats.

Refactoring routing recommendation (revised): Early signals suggested Opus 4.5 was better for refactoring, based on four false-positive dissatisfaction flags and small sample sizes. Sentiment detection and git retention both proved unreliable. Edit timeline analysis provided a more direct mechanistic signal: tracking every edit across all sessions revealed that Opus 4.5 rewrites previously-edited regions more often (17.1% vs 8.8%), though Opus 4.6’s small editing sample (n=29 tasks) means the confidence intervals overlap substantially.

Limitations

Single user: All data comes from one developer’s workflow. Results may not generalize to other users, codebases, or task distributions.

Observational, not experimental: Tasks were not randomly assigned to models. Opus 4.6 was used later chronologically and on different (often harder) tasks, confounding model effects with task effects.

Complexity confound: Opus 4.6’s different complexity mix (40.1% moderate-and-above vs 33.2% for Opus 4.5) inflates its resource usage metrics and may suppress its satisfaction scores relative to what it would achieve on equivalent tasks.

Sample asymmetry: The 8.6:1 ratio (1,742 vs 202 tasks) means Opus 4.5 estimates have narrower confidence intervals. Effect sizes for Opus 4.6 are less precise.

LLM-in-the-loop analysis: All task classification, sentiment analysis, and dissatisfaction auditing was performed by LLM agents (Claude Haiku and Sonnet), with human review of outputs and skepticism-driven re-auditing. No classification was done by hand.

Claude Code Early Access Program · Single-user exploratory case study · February 2026
